subject: Enable Meson Build system for Networkd
commitMessage:
Enable Meson Build system for Networkd

- This commit enables the meson build system for the
  phoshphor-networkd repo.

- There is a good difference in compile time when compiled with
  meson vs what we are achieving in auto tools.

autotools:
==========
time sh -c './bootstrap.sh;./configure ${CONFIGURE_FLAGS} --prefix=/usr --enable-oe-sdk;make;make check'
real	3m50.105s

meson:
=====
time sh -c 'meson builddir -Doe-sdk=enabled -Dtests=enabled;ninja -C builddir test'
real	1m0.091s

- This commit also enables the unit test support for networkd.
- This commit also addresses various code warnings that are also reported
  by meson.

Tested By:
1. build with debugoptimized & link time optimization
     meson builddir --buildtype=release -Db_lto=true -Doe-sdk=enabled
     ninja -C builddir test
2. build with coverage information
     meson builddir -Db_coverage=true -Doe-sdk=enabled
     ninja coverage -C builddir

- Code compiles both in arm & x86 sdks without errors or warnings.
- tested with all options enabled, and that compiles without any problem.

Signed-off-by: Manojkiran Eda <manojkiran.eda@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Iabc6116ebdb31b1dcf26f00b20581bbba3a1cfa3

In sdbusplus, I created a tool (which is exported) called 'sdbus++-gendir' that automatically generates all these pieces.  I suggest looking at the 'example/meson.build' in that repository to understand how it is used.  This tool will let you eliminate this tree of meson.build files under xyz/...

Patrick,

I did try using the sdbus++-gendir tool today,i was able to generate all the server.cpp,hpp files in the respective directories in one shot which is awesome.

But meson refuses to compile as meson tries to compile , as it find the same name server.cpp both under IP as well as under VLAN,as all these object files are generated under the same builddirectory(without the directory structure).

Code Snip:
custom_gen_files = files(
    run_command(
        sdbusgen_prog,
        '--tool', sdbuspp,
        '--output', meson.current_build_dir(),
        'xyz',
        check: true
    ).stdout().strip().split('\n')
)

builddir/xyz
└── openbmc_project
    └── Network
        ├── IP
        │   ├── Create
        │   │   ├── client.hpp
        │   │   ├── server.cpp
        │   │   └── server.hpp
        │   └── Create.md

        │   │   ├── server.cpp

            ├── Create
            │   ├── client.hpp
            │   ├── server.cpp
            │   └── server.hpp
            └── Create.md


Error :
ERROR: Multiple producers for Ninja target "libnetworkd@sta/server.cpp.o". Please rename your targets.

Do you know any better way to generate object files in the sub directories ? without using the subdir() in meson ? i one way i can think of is to rename the server.cpp to add the directory structure to it manually ?

I don't see anything wrong with the results of the 'run_command' call, but I suspect something is wrong with how you're asking to have those files included into your library/executable (I'll need to see that to help debug).

I've been working on converting phosphor-dbus-interfaces to use mesonbuild and I am using the `sdbus++-gen` there.  I've uploaded the WIP commit for you to take a look at as an example:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/33415

It turns out this was a bug with meson that was only fixed in 0.54.1.  Yocto is upgraded to 0.54.2 and I'm pushing up a change to the CI scripts to update as well.  You'll want to update your minimum version above to 0.54.1, which I've similarly done in that phosphor-dbus-interfaces commit.

The .in files have some config values that were replaced by autotools like "BusName=@DEFAULT_BUSNAME@". Have you verified this replacement still takes place? The meson 'copy' directive will just copy the input file to the output file.

To make the variable replacement you can do the following to tell meson to use the config values:
configure_file(
        input: xyz.openbmc_project.Network.service.in,
        output: 'xyz.openbmc_project.Network.service',
        configuration: conf_data,
        install: true,
        install_dir: systemd_system_unit_dir)
why dl is required?
all this dependency check should it go under test/meson.build?
why threads is required?
still valid? We're on dev-5.8 now.
tab here and line 180

If you want code coverage to be automatically generated, you'd need to build the tests from this meson.build file instead of having a test/meson.build file.

If you don't want code coverage, need to change this logic to:
if not build_tests.disabled()
    subdir('test')
endif
I'd have to look it up but in a code review William explained why this was the case. Otherwise this builds by default even though you don't specify the test option (you can verify yourself).

> If you want code coverage to be automatically generated, you'd need to build the tests from this meson.build file instead of having a test/meson.build file.

Was this a bug in older versions of meson?  I don't know why this would be true.  The 'subdir' directive is much more like a #include.  I would be surprised if there is different generated behavior for code-coverage based on the use of 'subdir' vs literally including the same content.
We never got much feedback upstream on this, https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/issues/6747 is the bug. I def hit and so did Lei. I haven't checked recently to see if something got fixed.
Yeah, that is unfortunate.  I really don't like us creating massive hard-to-read meson files as a workaround of an upstream bug.  This isn't my repo though.
why do we need this option? we can directly hard code it.
